title: Protocol for generation of 3D bone marrow surrogate microenvironments in a rotary cell culture system
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Step 1: Static pre-seeding of gelatin scaffold with HS-5 BMSC line
Timing: 5 h 30 min total
Timing: 30 min each for steps 1 and 2
Timing: 4 h 30 min for step 3
This section details the method for the static pre-seeding of BMSC in the gelatin scaffold (Spongostan™).
Preparation and cutting of the gelatin scaffolds (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1888-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Preparation of the scaffolds and the RCCS™ bioreactor
(A) Preparation of scaffolds from a cube of gelatin sponge (Spongostan™).
(B) Positioning of scaffolds in the 96-well suspension culture plate and HS-5 BMSC seeding.
(C and D) The RCCS™ 4DQ bioreactor (Synthecon, Inc,): the bioreactor is composed by a working station (C) with 4 independent positions for vessels and a power supply (D) with a tachometer controlling the speed of rotation of each vessel. The rotation of vessels is counterclockwise and maintains the scaffolds in a free fall condition simulating microgravity. The dynamic culture allows optimal mass transfer, delivery of nutrients and of oxygen, avoiding cell sedimentation.
(E) High Aspect Ratio Vessel (HARV): it is composed by one Plug Fill port, two syringe ports and a silicon membrane for gas exchange.
(F) High Aspect Ratio Vessel (HARV) with the Plug Fill port opened.
Under sterile conditions, in a laminar flow hood, open the blister containing the gelatin sponge (Spongostan™) and place it in a Petri dish. Gelatin sponge is supplied as a cube of 10 mmx10 mmx10 mm.
Using a scalpel cut the sponge into 3 slices of about 3 mm each.
With a 4 mm diameter punch, cut four equal cylinders per slice. It is possible to obtain 12 cylinders/scaffolds per sponge with dimensions 4 mm in diameter by 3 mm in height.

Retrieval of HS-5 BMSC by trypsin treatment. Counting and dilution of cell suspension.
Detach HS-5 BMSC cells from the culture flask by trypsin treatment and re-suspend them in CTM (DMEM+10% FBS), the volume depends on the flask (for T75 >5 mL for T25<5 mL).
Count live HS-5 BMSCs by trypan blue exclusion method.
Re-suspend the cells at the concentration of 10 × 106 cells/mL.
Seeding of gelatin scaffolds with HS-5 BMSCs and static incubation (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Place one gelatin scaffold per well in a 96-well, U-bottom, cell suspension plate.
Seed 200000 HS-5 BMSCs per scaffold (corresponding to 20 μL of cell suspension) allowing the entire volume (20 μL) to be absorbed by the sponge to homogenously distribute HS-5 BMSCs within the scaffold.
For a better distribution of the cells inside the scaffolds, slowly pipette each scaffold 3 times with a p100 micropipette equipped with a tip whose extremity is cut off (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1888-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. How to pipette each scaffold with a cut tip
Incubate the 96-well plate in a humidified incubator at 5% CO2 and 37°C for 4 h.
Critical: The gelatin scaffolds are very light and electrostatic and tend, if not well positioned, to exit the plate when located under the sterile hood. It is therefore advisable to position the scaffolds in any well of the plate with the help of forceps. To prevent evaporation of the medium in the wells containing the scaffolds, fill the empty wells surrounding the scaffolds with PBS.
Step 2: Dynamic seeding in the RCCS™ bioreactor of gelatin scaffold with HS-5 BMSC
Timing: 18 h

This section describes how to complete efficiently the seeding of BMSCs in the scaffolds under dynamic conditions in the RCCS™ bioreactor (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C and 1D). This step avoids cell sedimentation, favoring the homogeneous distribution of the cells within the scaffold.
The RCCS™4DQ bioreactor is equipped with four independent vessel stations (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C) and a tachometer for rotation control (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D). The vessel rotation on a horizontal axis (clinorotation) maintains the scaffolds in a free-fall condition (mimicking microgravity), generating a constant dynamic fluid flow. This guarantees an optimal mass transfer, which results in optimal viability of the cells within the scaffolds (Ferrarini et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6], 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]). Moreover, the HARV vessels are equipped with a gas exchange membrane that favors the optimal oxygenation of the scaffolds.
Preparation of HARV vessel, transfer of scaffolds from 96-well plate to HARV vessel and dynamic seeding in the RCCS™ bioreactor.
Take a new 10 mL Disposable High Aspect Ratio Vessel (HARV) and wash it by inserting 5 mL PBS through the open plug fill port (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E and 1F).
With a 5 mL pipette, through the plug fill port, remove the PBS.
With a p200 micropipette remove any residual PBS.
Through the plug fill port, add 600 μL of pre-warmed medium (DMEM+10%FBS) to the vessel.
Using a p100 pipette with a cut tip, carefully aspirate the scaffolds from the wells and one by one transfer them, through the plug fill port, in the HARV vessels (up to 3 scaffolds/vessel).
Close the plug fill port and place the vessels in the vessel station of the bioreactor, inside the incubator at 37°C and 5% CO2.
Dynamic seeding, in the RCCS™ bioreactor, of gelatin scaffolds with HS-5 BMSC.
Set the tachometer to a rotation speed of 7.5 rpm and leave the scaffolds overnight inside the vessel.

Step 3: Dynamic culture of CLL cells (MEC-1) or MM cells (MM.1S) inside HS-5 BMSCs populated scaffolds
Timing: 48–72 h total
Timing: 5 h 30 min for step 6
Timing: 30 min preparation + 48 h/72 h culture for step 7
This section explains how to seed the scaffolds, previously populated with stromal cells, with tumor cells and how to keep them in culture in the RCCS™ bioreactor.
Retrieval of tumor cells (MEC-1 or MM.1S) from the culture flasks and dynamic seeding in the scaffolds.
Retrieve MEC-1 cells or MM.1S cells from culture flasks, centrifuge them at 410 × g for 5 min and re-suspend them in ≅5 mL fresh pre-warmed medium (RPMI+10%FBS).
Count cells by trypan blue exclusion method.
If the vessel contains one or two scaffolds:
Re-suspend MEC-1 cells in CTM (RPMI+10%FBS) to obtain a final concentration of 10 × 106 cells/mL.       OR
Re-suspend MM1.S cells in CTM (RPMI+10%FBS) to obtain a final concentration of 2.5 × 106 cells/mL.
To the HARV vessel add 2 × 106 MEC-1 (corresponding to 200 μL of cell suspension) or 500 × 103 MM.1S (corresponding to 200 μL of cell suspension) for each scaffold through the plug fill port to obtain inside the vessel a final volume of 800 μL for 1 scaffold or 1 mL for 2 scaffolds. (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]-1).
If the vessel contains three scaffolds:
Re-suspend MEC-1 cells in CTM (RPMI+10%FBS) to obtain a final concentration of 15 × 106 cells/mL.       OR
Re-suspend MM1.S cells in CTM (RPMI+10%FBS) to obtain a final concentration of 3.75 × 106 cells/mL.

To the HARV vessel add 6 × 106 MEC-1 (corresponding to 400 μL of cell suspension) or 1.5 × 106 MM.1S (corresponding to 400 μL of cell suspension) through the plug fill port to obtain inside the vessel a final volume of 1 mL (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]-1).
Set rotation speed to 7.5 rpm and allow the cell seeding to proceed for 5 h in the incubator at 37°C and 5%CO2.
Dynamic culture of populated scaffolds.
Pre-warmed CTM (RPMI+10%FBS) is added to the vessels through the syringe ports using sterile 5 mL syringes (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]) using the following steps:
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1888-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. How to fill vessels with medium step by step
Insert a sterile 5 mL syringe in a syringe port with the plunger removed (syringe A in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Insert another 5 mL sterile syringe (syringe B in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]) to the second port.
Fill syringe A with 5 mL of CTM (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].4).
With syringe B, slowly draw the air out of the vessel and let the medium enter from the second syringe (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].5).
Repeat steps ii-iii to fill the vessel with a total of ≅11 mL CTM.
Close the syringe ports and discard the syringes.
Put the vessel in the bioreactor in the incubator at 37°C and 5%CO2.
Start the culture by setting the rotation speed initially to 7.5 rpm and then increasing it, up to 14 rpm, to prevent the sedimentation of the scaffolds and to maintain them in a free-fall condition.
Keep the scaffolds in culture in the bioreactor for 48–72 h. If 3D culture continues, change the medium.
Note: If air bubbles are formed, these can be removed with the two syringes placed in the syringe ports.

Note: Speed rotation must be settled to maintain scaffolds in a free-fall condition: it means that the scaffolds must neither precipitate under the action of gravity, nor turn in the vessel under the action of the centrifugal force. These forces must be balanced by adjusting the rotational speed usually starting from 7.5 rpm and up to 14 rpm.
Note: It is important to monitor the color of the medium: if the color of the medium turns yellow it is important to change it. Normally when active proliferating cell lines are cultured (as MEC-1 cells), medium must be changed more frequently (after 48 h) than primary slowly or not proliferating cells.
Medium change.
Insert a sterile 5 mL syringe in a syringe port and carefully aspirate 2 mL of medium. Discard it or put it in a 15 mL tube for future analysis.
Open the second syringe port (in order to let the air enter/removing the vacuum) and with the syringe aspirate the remaining medium paying attention to not remove any scaffolds.
Insert a sterile 5 mL syringe (B) in a syringe port (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Insert another 5 mL sterile syringe (A), removing the plunger, in the second syringe port and fill it with CTM as explained in Step 3.7a (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Put the vessel in the bioreactor in the incubator and continue the culture.
Note: It is possible to discard the medium or to store it at −20°C for further analysis.
Optional: You may recover cells in the SN medium by centrifuging it at 410 × g.
Critical: Change the medium slowly and carefully to avoid removal of the scaffolds or generation of turbulence inside the vessel.
Step 4: Recovering of the scaffolds from the RCCS™ bioreactor and subsequent analysis
Timing: 1 h

This section explains how to recover scaffolds, SN and cells in SN from the vessel, and how to process them for subsequent analysis.
Recovering of scaffolds, SN and cells in SN from the vessels.
With a syringe, gently aspirate 2 mL of SN from the vessel through a syringe port and put it in a 15 mL tube.
Open the plug fill port and pour the content of the vessel into a Petri dish or a 6-well plate scaffolds and SN.
Enzymatic digestion of scaffolds and retrieval of cells for counting and flow cytometry.
Add 500 μL of Liberase™ 25 μg/mL in a FACS tube and place one scaffold. Alternatively, add 1 mL of Liberase™ for the digestion of 2 or 3 scaffolds.
Let the tube/tubes incubate for 10 min at 37°C for the complete digestion of the scaffolds.
Vortex tube to facilitate cell disaggregation and to re-suspend cells. (Alternatively pipette digested scaffold).
Block the enzymatic digestion adding 500 μL (or 1 mL FBS if using 1 mL of Liberase™) of FBS.
Count cells by trypan blue exclusion.
Centrifuge tube/tubes at 410 × g for 5 min, wash cells with 1 mL of PBS.
Centrifuge again as in f and discard SN.
Use cells for successive staining and flow cytometry.
Note: The ratio of Liberase™ to FBS is 1:1.
If apoptosis detection must be performed wash cells with the Binding Buffer (included in the apoptosis detection kit).
Fixation of scaffolds for confocal analysis.
Add 300 μL of PFA 4% per well of a 48-well plate.
Insert 1 scaffold per well in order to fix it and let it fix ON at room temperature (RT).
Wash scaffolds with Blocking Solution for subsequent staining and confocal analysis.
Lysis of scaffolds for Western blot analysis.
Place one scaffold in a 1.5 mL vial.

Lyse scaffold with 100 μL/scaffold of Lysis Buffer for 30 min in ice (or 0°C).
Lysis of scaffolds for real time PCR.
Place one scaffold in a 1.5 mL.
Lyse one scaffold with 1 mL of TRIzol at RT and freeze at −20°C.
Recovering of cells in SN for counting and flow cytometry.
Recover SN from the Petri dish or 6-well plate and put it in a 15 mL tube.
Centrifuge tube at 410 × g for 5 min to pellet cells, remove SN and re-suspend in 5 mL of PBS and count them by trypan blue exclusion dye.
Place cells in facs tubes.
Centrifuge cells at 410 × g for 5 min and stain cells for flow cytometric analysis (as explained in Step 5.16).
Recovering of SNs for ELISA test or metalloproteases (MMPs) evaluation by zymography.
Add SN in another 15 mL tube, eventually aliquot it in 1.5 mL vials-eppendorf and store it at −20°C.
SN can successively be analyzed by ELISA to assess concentration of soluble factors (Cytokines, chemokines, growth factors) or subjected to zymography for MMPs assessment.
Step 5: Characterization of scaffolds
Timing: 3 h
This section describes how to evaluate the cells present in the scaffold by flow cytometry and the cell distribution and organization, within the scaffold, by confocal analysis.
Staining of cells retrieved from the scaffolds upon digestion with Liberase™ for flow cytometric analysis. Usually, the expected number of cells retrieved from the scaffolds (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A) is:
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1888-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Characterization and organization of cells inside the scaffold
(A) number of cells (mean ± SD) usually retrieved from the scaffold after 48 h or 72 h of 3D culture in bioreactor.
(B) Characterization by flow cytometry of HS-5 cells, MEC-1 cells and MM1.S cells.

(C) Characterization of scaffolds populated with HS-5 BMSCs and MEC-1 (LEFT) or MM.1S (RIGHT).
(D) Confocal analysis of scaffold populated with HS-5 BMSC line (bar size=50 μm; Leica TC sp5).
(E) Confocal analysis of scaffold populated with HS-5 BMSC line and CLL cell line MEC (bar size=50 μm; Leica TC sp5).
(F) Confocal analysis of scaffold populated with HS-5 BMSC line and MM cell line MM.1S (bar size=50 μm; Olympus Fluo view).
HS-5+MEC-1 after 48 h of culture: ≅1500 × 103. HS-5+MEC-1 after 72 h of culture: ≅2500 × 103. HS-5+MM1.S after 24 h (reported in Belloni et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]) and 48 h of culture: ≅1000 × 103. Cells retrieved from the scaffolds populated with MEC-1 cells and BMSC are stained for anti-human CD19-PC7 (B cells marker, to detect the percentage of MEC-1 cells) and anti-human CD73-APC (MSC marker, to detect the percentage of BMSC) (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B and 4C). Cells retrieved from the scaffolds populated with MM1.S cells and BMSC are stained for anti-human CD38-PE (alternatively it is possible to use CD138-FITC) (Plasmacells marker, to detect the percentage of MM1.S cells) and anti-human CD73-APC (MSC marker, to detect the percentage of BMSC) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B and 4C).
Incubate cells (≅ 500 × 103 cells) and antibodies for 15 min at 4°C: for CD19-PC7 add 5 μL of antibody to 200 μL of cell suspension; for CD38-PE add 0.5 μL of antibody to 200 μL of cell suspension (alternatively 10 μL of CD138-FITC); for CD73-APC add 2 μL of antibody to200 μL of cell suspension.
Wash cells with 1 mL of washing medium, successively centrifuge FACS tubes at 410 × g for 5 min.
Filter cells with 35 μm cell strainer caps before running FACS tubes on a cytofluorimeter in order to remove eventual cell aggregates.

Run cells on a cytofluorimeter and analyze data (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B and 4C).
Cells retrieved from the scaffolds populated with MM.1S and BMSC are stained with anti-human CD73-APC and anti-human CD38-PE.
Incubate cells and antibodies for 15 min at 4°C.
Wash cells with 1 mL of washing medium, successively centrifuge FACS tubes at 410 × g for 5 min.
Filter cells with 35 μm cell strainer caps before running the FACS tubes on a flow cytometer to remove eventual cell aggregates.
Run cells on a flow cytometer and analyze data (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B and 4C).
Staining of scaffolds for confocal analysis (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D–4F).
After fixation with PFA 4% ON, in the 48 well, scaffolds are washed with Blocking Solution and permeabilized with 500 μL Triton X100 0.3% in Blocking Solution for 20 min RT.
Scaffolds are then washed with 500 μL of PBS.
Scaffold can be stained with primary and secondary antibodies and visualized by confocal microscope (Leica TC sp5 or Olympus Fluo view).
To evaluate cell organization and distribution inside the scaffold, scaffolds are stained with Phalloidin 565 diluted 1:50 in PBS and Hoechst 33342 (5 μg/mL) for 1 h at RT. To visualize tumor cells we stained them with 2 μM Vybrant® CFDA SE Cell tracer before dynamic seeding using the manufacturer’s instructions (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D–4F).
Step 6: Addition of drugs to 3D cell cultures
Timing: 1 h
Ibrutinib (Ibr) treatment to evaluate its effect in mobilizing CLL cells from the scaffolds.
Prepare one vessel as an untreated (Unt) condition and one vessel for Ibr treatment, both with 3 scaffolds populated with HS-5 BMSCs and CLL cells (as described in parts 1 and 2 for HS-5 and in part 3 for MEC-1 cells).

After 72 h of dynamic culture in the bioreactor, retrieve 1–2 mL of medium from the vessels with a syringe and aliquot into a 15 mL tube. During this operation let the scaffolds settle on the opposite site of the vessels in order to minimize their perturbation.
Remove the syringe, open the Plug Fill port and gently remove the remaining medium containing cells that did not enter the scaffolds.
Place the removed cells/media in the 15 mL tube from step b.
Count cells in SNs to verify that the number of cells entered in the scaffolds are homogeneously distributed between the 2 vessels (Unt and Ibr).
Clarify SNs by centrifuging tubes for 5 min at 1500 rpm RT.
Discard the cells that did not enter the scaffolds and retrieve medium.
Through the syringe ports, as explained previously, (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]) gently re-add recovered SNs inside the vessels with or without the addition of Ibr 1 μM and avoid the generation of turbulence.
Critical: When removing medium from the vessels be careful not to remove any of the scaffolds.
Bortezomib (Btz) treatment to evaluate its action in inducing MM cells death.
Prepare one vessel for Unt condition and one vessel for Btz treatment both containing up to 3 scaffolds.
Through one syringe port with a 1 mL syringe, add Btz diluted in a little amount of medium (≅300 μL) in order to obtain a concentration of 10 nM inside the vessel.
Step 7: Assessment of the impact of drugs on tumor cells
Timing: 2 h for step 20
Timing: 1 h 30 min for step 21
This section shows how to evaluate the impact of Ibr on CLL cells and of Btz on MM cells.
Assessment of the impact of Ibr on CLL cells (Barbaglio et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).

After 5 h of dynamic culture in the presence or the absence of Ibr, as previously described in Step 6.18, retrieve both the scaffolds and the SN that contains cells that are mobilized from the scaffolds. The scaffolds are then digested in FACS tubes by adding 500 μL of Liberase™ (as explained in Step 4.10) for 10 min at 37°C to retrieve the cells.
Count cells present in the SN by trypan blue exclusion method in both conditions (untreated and treated) to evaluate mobilization induced by Ibr.
As a control, count the cells inside the scaffold in both conditions (untreated and treated).
Stain CLL cells present in the SN for CD19-PC7 (as explained in Step 5.16a and b).
To evaluate viability of cells:
wash cells with 1 mL of Binding Buffer (provided in the apoptosis detection kit and prepared following the manufacturer’s instructions) and centrifuge tubes at 410 × g.
Discard SN.
Stain cells with 5 μL of Annexin V (AnnV) for 10 min at RT.
Wash cells adding 1 mL of Binding Buffer and centrifuging at 410 × g.
Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in 500 μL of Binding Buffer.
Add 7 μL of Propidium Iodide (PI) immediately before running the tube on a flow cytometer.
Stain (as explained in Step 5.16a and b) cells inside the scaffold for CD73-APC, CD19-PC7 in order to evaluate the percentage of CLL cells inside the scaffold. To assess their viability, stain cells for AnnV and PI (as explained in point e).
Finally run cells on a flow cytometer in order to characterize the composition of scaffolds, of mobilized cells and to detect their viability.

Note: Cells inside the scaffold or mobilized cells can be characterized by real time PCR and by Western blot to evaluate differences in gene expression and protein levels, respectively. For example, we demonstrated that CLL cells with inactive HS1 (a protein involved in the regulation of cytoskeleton activity), are more likely to be retained within the scaffolds despite the presence of Ibr, whose mobilizing effect is mainly exerted on those with active HS1 (Barbaglio et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Assessment of the impact of Btz on MM cells (Belloni et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
After 24 h of dynamic culture in the presence or the absence of Btz, scaffolds are retrieved, as previously described in Step 5.16a and b, from the vessels and digested by means of 500 μL Liberase™.
Cells retrieved from the scaffolds are then counted by trypan blue exclusion dye in order to evaluate the percentage of dead cells (Trypan blue positive).
Stain cells for anti-human CD38-PE and AnnV or CD38-PC7 and AnnV/PI (as explained in part 5-point 1a and b for the staining with CD38-PE and CD38-PC7; as explained in Step 7.20a point 1a for staining with Ann V and PI) for flow cytometric analysis to detect the effects of the drug (Belloni et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]) (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A and 5B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1888-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Response to drugs
(A) Evaluation of the impact of Btz on scaffolds populated with HS-5 BMSC and MM.1S.
(B) Evaluation of the impact of Btz on MM.1S 2D culture and on scaffold populated with primary BMSCs and MM.1S.
Note: The three scaffolds per vessel can be used to evaluate different outcomes or different analyses; for example, one scaffold can be enzymatically digested to detect apoptosis of MM cells after Btz treatment, one scaffold can be fixed and stained for confocal analysis and so on.
Critical: For Western blot analysis consider lysing at least 2 scaffolds for both MM and CLL scaffolds.
